Classes¶

Postprocessing module to implement graph plot and file output.

class postprocessing.report.Report(metadata: Optional[dict] = None, generate_pdf: bool = False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Markdown Wrapper Class to implement matplolib graphs and file output with markdown syntax.

static parse_code(codeblock: str, language: str = 'python') → str[source]¶

Parse code to Markdown syntax.

Parameters

  • codeblock (str) – String input with the codeblock

  • language (str, optional) – Coding language to lint the code, defaults to “python”

Returns

String with the codeblock in markdown syntax

Return type

str

Parse dataframe to a markdown table showing the rows given by rows argument.

print(paragraph: str)[source]¶

Print plain text to report file in Markdown syntax.

Parameters

paragraph (str) – String paragraph to be printed in the report file

print_boxplot(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, labels: list, filename: str = 'boxplot.png', img_title: str = 'Box Plot', figsize: tuple = (15, 7), color: str = 'green', orient: str = 'v', same_scale: bool = False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Print to file the boxplot of the given data.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Pandas Dataframe with data to be plotted

  • labels (list) – List containing the column tags to be plotted

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “boxplot.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Box Plot”

  • figsize (tuple, optional) – Tuple with the image dimensions, defaults to (15, 7)

  • color (str, optional) – String with the color of the boxplot, defaults to “green”

  • orient (str, optional) – String for the orientation of the boxplot, defaults to “v”

  • same_scale (bool, optional) – Boolean to use the same scale for different boxes, defaults to False

print_clreport(t_test: numpy.ndarray, y_pred: numpy.ndarray, title: str = 'Classification report')[source]¶

Print the classification report to the report file.

Parameters

  • t_test (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the t_test values

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the y predicted values

  • title (str, optional) – String title for the classification report, defaults to “Classification report”

print_confusion_matrix(model: sklearn.base.BaseEstimator, X_test: numpy.ndarray, t_test: numpy.ndarray, xlabel: str, ylabel: str, filename: str = 'confusion_matrix.png', img_title: str = 'Confusion Matrix', size_dpi: int = 100, **kwargs)[source]¶

Print confusion matrix plot of the given model.

Parameters

  • model (BaseEstimator) – Model which be used to print the confusion matrix

  • X_test (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the X_test values

  • t_test (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the t_test values

  • xlabel (str) – String with the label of the x axe

  • ylabel (str) – String with the label of the y axe

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “confusion_matrix.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Confusion Matrix”

  • size_dpi (int, optional) – Number for the resolution dpi of the image, defaults to 100

print_confusion_matrix_DNN(t_test: numpy.ndarray, y_pred: numpy.ndarray, xlabel: str, ylabel: str, title: str)[source]¶

Print confusion matrix plot of the given DNN model.

Parameters

  • t_test (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the t_test values

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the y predicted values

  • xlabel (str) – String with the label of the x axe

  • ylabel (str) – String with the label of the y axe

  • title (str) – String with the title for the dataframe

print_dataframe(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, rows: int = 5)[source]¶

Print the dataframe with the given rows to the report file.

If the dataframe have more than 5 columns, will be divided to print in the report.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Pandas dataframe to be printed

  • rows (int, optional) – Number of rows of the dataframe to be printed, defaults to 5

print_hpcontrast(data: list, labels: list, alpha: float = 0.05)[source]¶

Contrast the hypoteses of the scores given in the list and print the results in the report.

Using Kurskal-Wallis and Tuckeyhsd tests.

Parameters

  • data (list) – List containing the metric results of the models

  • labels (list) – List containg the models tags

  • alpha (float, optional) – Number for the pValue of the test, defaults to 0.05

print_line()[source]¶

Print horizontal line to report file in Markdown syntax.

print_mean_acc_model(best_models: tuple, tag: str, filename: str = 'mean_accuracy.png', img_title: str = 'Mean Accuracy', **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot the mean accuracy of the model using its historial results to the report.

Parameters

  • best_models (tuple) – Tuple with the best models to print their mean accuracy curves

  • tag (str) – String with the tag of the model to be printed

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “mean_accuracy.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Mean Accuracy”

print_noformat(paragraph: str)[source]¶

Print plain text to report file escaping Markdown syntax.

Parameters

paragraph (str) – String paragraph to be printed in the report file with no format

print_roc_curve(t_test: numpy.ndarray, y_score: numpy.ndarray, filename: str = 'roc_curve.png', img_title: str = 'Roc Curve per class', figsize: tuple = (10, 8), xlabel: str = 'False Positive Rate', ylabel: str = 'True Positive Rate', legend_loc: str = 'lower right', **kwargs)[source]¶

Print roc curves for any labels of the given model.

Parameters

  • t_test (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the t_test values

  • y_score – Numpy array with the y score values

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “roc_curve.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Roc Curve per class”

  • figsize (tuple, optional) – Tuple with the image dimensions, defaults to (10, 8)

  • xlabel (str) – String with the label of the x axe

  • ylabel (str) – String with the label of the y axe

  • legend_loc (str) – String with the position of the legend in the figure

Print title to report file in Markdown syntax.

Parameters

  • title (str) – String title to be printed

  • h (int, optional) – Number with the header level, defaults to 1

print_val_curve_dnn(best_DNN: tuple, metric: str = 'accuracy', filename: str = 'validation_curve_dnn.png', img_title: str = 'Validation Curve', **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot the validation curve of the model using its historial results to the report.

Parameters

  • best_DNN (tuple) – Tuple with the best models to print their validation curves

  • metric (str, optional) – String with the metric used to perform the validation curve, defaults to “accuracy”

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “validation_curve_dnn.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Validation Curve”

print_validation_curve(model: sklearn.base.BaseEstimator, X: numpy.ndarray, y: numpy.ndarray, param_name: str, param_range=array([1.00000000e-06, 1.77827941e-05, 3.16227766e-04, 5.62341325e-03, 1.00000000e-01]), ylabel: str = 'Score', filename: str = 'validation_curve.png', img_title: str = 'Validation Curve', figsize: tuple = (10, 8), **kwargs)[source]¶

Print validation curve plot of the given model.

Parameters

  • model (BaseEstimator) – Model which be used to plot the validation curve

  • X (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the characteristic matrix

  • y (np.ndarray) – Numpy array with the predicted values

  • param_name (str) – String with the name of the hyperparameter

  • param_range (range, optional) – Logarithmic range for the hyperparameter values, defaults to np.logspace(-6, -1, 5)

  • ylabel (str, optional) – String with the label for the y axe, defaults to “Score”

  • filename (str, optional) – String with the filename of the output image, defaults to “validation_curve.png”

  • img_title (str, optional) – String with the title of the output image, defaults to “Validation Curve”

  • figsize (tuple, optional) – Tuple with the image dimensions, defaults to (10, 8)

save_image(figure: matplotlib.figure.Figure, filename: str, img_title: str, **kwargs)[source]¶

Image saving method to file and report.

Parameters

  • figure (plt.Figure) – Matplotlib figure to be printed in the report file

  • filename (str) – String with the filename of the output image

  • img_title (str) – String with the title of the output image
